title: What if my second vaccine dose is early or delayed? Here's what the CDC says
author: Jessica Roy
description: The second shot of the COVID vaccine does not need to happen precisely 21 or 28 days after the first to be effective.
cleaned_text: What if my second vaccine dose is early or delayed? Here's what the CDC says There's a lot of confusion out there about second doses of the COVID-19 vaccine. The COVID-19 [vaccine rollout has been chaotic in California](https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2021-02-02/california-covid-vaccine-rollout-lags-other-states). Guidance on [how to get the second dose](https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2021-01-29/county-by-county-heres-how-to-get-a-covid-19-vaccine-in-southern-california) has changed from "you have to make your own appointment" to "we'll tell you when to come back" to "OK, you should hear from us, but if you don't, just come back." The Los Angeles County department of public health admitted on Twitter that it had been [stressful](https://twitter.com/lapublichealth/status/1356391217114673152). People are also concerned about the timing of the second dose. Over at the [L.A. Times tip line](https://www.latimes.com/tips/), we've been getting inquiries about second dose appointments that are not precisely timed after the first. In its clinical trials, [Pfizer](https://www.latimes.com/science/story/2020-12-15/how-the-covid-19-vaccines-from-moderna-and-pfizer-compare-head-to-head) administered the second dose 21 days after the first. For [Moderna](https://www.latimes.com/science/story/2020-12-15/how-the-covid-19-vaccines-from-moderna-and-pfizer-compare-head-to-head), it was 28 days. According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the second dose should be administered as close to the recommended date as possible. But total precision isn't required. If it's a little earlier, that's allowed: "Second doses administered within a grace period of four days earlier than the recommended date for the second dose are still considered valid," the [CDC says on its website](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/info-by-product/clinical-considerations.html#Administration). A couple of weeks later is fine too. "If it is not feasible to adhere to the recommended interval and a delay in vaccination is unavoidable, the second dose of Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines may be administered up to six weeks (42 days) after the first dose." [First doses of COVID-19 vaccine have become limited in California. When will that change?](https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2021-02-09/first-doses-of-covid-19-vaccine-have-become-limited-in-california-when-will-that-change) California is reserving large amounts of COVID-19 vaccine supply for people needing their second dose, leaving fewer first doses available. [Dr. Diane Griffin](https://www.jhsph.edu/faculty/directory/profile/281/diane-e-griffin) is a virologist at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health who studies immune responses to viral infections and vaccines. She said [in an interview with The Times](https://www.latimes.com/science/newsletter/2021-01-27/coronavirus-today-vaccine-inquities-los-angeles-coronavirus-today) that while there aren't studies of the efficacy of these vaccines when the second dose isn't administered right on schedule, based on what we do know about other vaccines and immune responses, there's no reason it won't work just as well. "I think that perfection is the enemy of the good," she said. In other words: Don't stress about your second dose being a little early or late. The important thing is that you get it. For the latest news on the coronavirus and vaccines in L.A. and California, [subscribe to our newsletter](https://membership.latimes.com/newsletters/). Staff writer [Amina Khan](https://www.latimes.com/people/amina-khan) contributed to this report. The process for getting a COVID-19 vaccine varies county to county.
